div1.p:
United States District Court Western District of Washington Northern Division
In re petition of Ng Kwack Kang for Writ of Habeas Corpus
#3157 Brief of United States.
Statement of the Case. Ng Kwack Kang applied for admission at Seattle as the son of an American-born Chinese residing in Boston. The Immigration authorities denied him admission because the alleged relationship was not established. Petition for writ of habeas corpus was then filed, embracing many charges, among which the following legal points are noted: I. The function of habeas corpus is to test the legality of confinement, and unless that appears contrary to law the writ should not be granted. In the instant case petitioner is held for deportation as a rejected chinese alien who applied for admission, the authority for custody being a Department of Labor warrant the validity of which is not attacked. This warrant is based on the rejection made by the immigration officials at the port of entry, affirmed on appeal to the Department of Labor. In chinese cases it has been construed proper, upon habeas corpus, to enquire into the question of fairness of hearing and abuse of discretion by the examining immigration officils and in the event no fault is found on those scores, to remand the petitioner for deportation. U.S. vs Ju Toy, 49 L Ed 1040 et seq.

II. If the hearing was fair and no abuse of discretion appears, the writ must be dismissed. The power to admit, exclude, or expel aliens has been confided entirely to the political department of the government, except in the single instance of hearings before United States Commissioners on deportation charges filed against chinese unlawfully found in the country. In such cases an appeal to the District Court, with trial de novo, is authorized. Sec. 13, Act 13 Sept 1888, ch. 1015. The case of aliens who have not landedm and all other cases, being political matters of the highest order, are confided to the executive department of the government, and its action, if fair and free from abuse of discretion is final. The entire record in petitioners case is on file herein for examination on those points.
In re Ng Key Tung #2897, Neterer J, 1-21-15 Ex parte Moola Singh, 207 F 708, Neterer J In re Chin Quock Wah #2971, Neterer J 5-10-15 In re Tang Tun, 168 F 488; aff. 56 L Ed 606 White vs Gregory 213 F 768 Zakonaite vs Wolf 57 L Ed 218 Nishimura Ekiu vs US, 35 L Ed 1146 Ex p. Hidekuny Iwata 219 F 610 Ex p. Bun Chew 220 F 387 In re Can Pon 168 F 479 In re D Charlie Mark 179 F 292 US vs Chin Yow 208 8 US vs Ju Toy 49 L Ed 1040 In re Gin Fung 100 F 389 In re Tsuie Shee and Quan You_G_, 325-15
Section 8, Act 13 Sept 1888, page 15 Chinese Exclusion Laws pamphlet; and Sec. 7 of Act 5 May 1892, page 21 same pamphlet, are the legal basis for Rule 9-b of the immigration department, which reads: "The lawful wife of an American citizen of the chinese race may be admitted for the purpose of joining her husband; and the lawful children of such a citizen partake in his citizenship and are therefore entitled to admission. In every such case, convincing evidence of citizenship and relationship shall be exacted."

Under this rule the immigration officials at Seattle made the rejection, not being convinced of the relationship claimed. Upon appeal, the Secretary of Labor affirmed the rejection, and this is final. The record also fails to show convincing evidence of citizenship
Sections 22, 23, and 38 of the Immigration Act of Feb 20 1907 as amended, pages 13, 14, 17, pamphlet laws, contain further authority for the rules and regulations of the Department of Labor. These rules bear on chinese cases, in as much as the law requires a chinese to first pass the requirements of this law before being examined under the exclusion act.
In the Tang Tun case 168 F 488, at p. 496 it is said: "Under such circumstances we do not understand, in view of the law as declared by the Supreme Court I' n the cases hereinbefore referred to, that ANY court is authorized to review the action of the Department of Commerce and Labor in the matter of admitting or weighing evidence, or to consider whether the conslusions drawn by its officers were right or wrong."
